args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject exerts a causal or shaping effect on the object (e.g., one factor influencing behaviors, perceptions, relationships, or communication patterns).
args.justification: All relations have the same subject (social media) and describe its causal or shaping impact on various human or societal domains (communication, relationships, behaviors, perceptions). They already share the canonical_rel_name 'influences'; however, there are two slightly different canonical_rel_desc variants and two different rel_cls values ('social_media_impact_relation' vs 'influence_relation'). Unifying the description and assigning a single specific class 'social_media_impact_relation' across these instances makes the schema consistent, while keeping rel_cls_group as CAUSALITY unchanged.
args.remark: Standardized the influence predicate description and specialized the relation class to social_media_impact_relation for all social-media-impact edges in this cluster.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject exerts a causal or shaping effect on the object (e.g., one factor influencing behaviors, perceptions, relationships, or communication patterns).
executed_decisions.justification: All relations have the same subject (social media) and describe its causal or shaping impact on various human or societal domains (communication, relationships, behaviors, perceptions). They already share the canonical_rel_name 'influences'; however, there are two slightly different canonical_rel_desc variants and two different rel_cls values ('social_media_impact_relation' vs 'influence_relation'). Unifying the description and assigning a single specific class 'social_media_impact_relation' across these instances makes the schema consistent, while keeping rel_cls_group as CAUSALITY unchanged.
executed_decisions.remark: Standardized the influence predicate description and specialized the relation class to social_media_impact_relation for all social-media-impact edges in this cluster.
